video.title: Python and Pygame Tutorial - Build Tetris! Full GameDev Course
video.description:
Learn how to code Tetris in Python with Pygame in this full tutorial. This Python Pygame tutorial is meant for intermediate programmers with some experience, but everyone is welcome to follow along.

🎥 How to Install Pygame: https://goo.gl/CEhksw  
💻 Starter File: https://pastebin.com/embed_js/VztMLjCc
💻 Full Code: https://pastebin.com/embed_js/yaWTeF6y  

If you have trouble downloading the code from the links, make sure you click on DOWNLOAD RAW and then copy the code from there.

Tutorial from Tech With Tim.
Check out Tim's channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC4JX40jDee_tINbkjycV4Sg

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://medium.freecodecamp.org

topLevelComment.author: Toni Ruottu
topLevelComment.text: It seems this tutorial is doing a good job in motivating people to try programming. Here are some tips that were missing from the tutorial. Run the program *very* often and do *very* small changes to make sure your code keeps working. It is a good practice to avoid "magic values" in your code. If you use (0, 0, 0) to represent black, write black = (0, 0, 0). If your play area width on screen is game board width times block size in pixels, write play_area_width_px = game_board_width * block_size_px. Also, in this tutorial we are inventing new rules for Tetris as we go. Since we are trying reimplementing an existing game we'd be better off following some existing specification. For example, we might decide to implement the "Standard Rotation System" that specifies one specific way of rotating the blocks.

replies.author: Charles
replies.text: return inc from the clear_rows() and then increment a score variable, defined at the beginning of main, depending on how many lines were cleared (inc). Personally I decided to add 1200 for a tetris, 300 for a triple, 200 for a double, and 80 for a single, just like the original NES/Gameboy version

replies.author: brendan siche
replies.text:
The nested for statement are not really easy to understand, but try searching on google to find how to decompose them.

For exemple, one of those "difficult" statement
 grid = [[(0, 0, 0) for x in range(10)] for x in range(20)]

We can split this in two steps

Step one : [(0, 0, 0) for x in range(10)]
step two : [(step one) for x in range(20)]

step one is filling each "square" of an individual line
from 0 to 10 (for x in range(10)
fill the square with (0,0,0) (black)

Then repeat this step for every line on the grid(20 of them)
from 0 to 20 (for x in range(20)
repeat step 1

this give you the two dimensional grid.

If you're not used yet to multidimensional array, you should practice the concept in some simpler exercices, try some Kata on codewars !
